**Wentworth Earl Miller III** (born June 2, 1972)[1] is a British-American
actor, model, and screenwriter. He rose to prominence following his role as
[Michael Scofield](/wiki/Michael_Scofield "Michael Scofield") in the five
seasons of the [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting
Company") series _[Prison Break](/wiki/Prison_Break "Prison Break")_ , for
which he received a [Golden Globe Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden
Globe Award") nomination for Best Actor in a Leading Role. He made his
screenwriting debut with the 2013 thriller film
_[Stoker](/wiki/Stoker_\(film\) "Stoker \(film\)")_. In 2014, he began playing
[Leonard Snart / Captain Cold](/wiki/Captain_Cold "Captain Cold") in a
recurring role on [The CW](/wiki/The_CW "The CW") series _[The
Flash](/wiki/The_Flash_\(2014_TV_series\) "The Flash \(2014 TV series\)")_
before becoming a series regular on the spin-off _[Legends of
Tomorrow](/wiki/Legends_of_Tomorrow "Legends of Tomorrow")_. Miller reprised
his role as Michael Scofield for the [fifth
season](/wiki/Prison_Break_\(season_5\) "Prison Break \(season 5\)") of the
limited-run _Prison Break_ revival, which aired on April 4, 2017 and concluded
on May 30, 2017.

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wentworth_Miller&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Miller was born in [Chipping Norton](/wiki/Chipping_Norton "Chipping Norton"),
[Oxfordshire](/wiki/Oxfordshire "Oxfordshire"), the son of American
parents,[2] Roxann (née Palm), a special education teacher, and Wentworth E.
Miller II, a lawyer and teacher.[1][3] His father, a [Rhodes
Scholar](/wiki/Rhodes_Scholarship "Rhodes Scholarship"), was studying at
[Oxford](/wiki/University_of_Oxford "University of Oxford") at the time of
Miller's birth.[4] Miller said in 2003 that his father is black and his mother
is white.[5] His father is of African-American, Jamaican, German, and English
ancestry; his mother is of Russian, Swedish, French, Dutch, Syrian, and
Lebanese ancestry.[6][7]

Miller's family moved to [Park Slope, Brooklyn](/wiki/Park_Slope,_Brooklyn
"Park Slope, Brooklyn") when he was a year old.[4][8] He graduated from
[Princeton University](/wiki/Princeton_University "Princeton University") in
1995 with a [bachelor's degree](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree "Bachelor's degree")
in [English literature](/wiki/English_literature "English literature"). While
at Princeton, he performed with the [a cappella](/wiki/A_cappella "A
cappella") group the [Princeton Tigertones](/wiki/Princeton_Tigertones
"Princeton Tigertones"), and was a member of the [Quadrangle
Club](/wiki/Quadrangle_Club "Quadrangle Club") and the [Colonial
Club](/wiki/Colonial_Club "Colonial Club").[9]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wentworth_Miller&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Wentworth_Miller_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/170px-
Wentworth_Miller_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wentworth_Miller_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wentworth_Miller_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg "Enlarge")

Miller at the 2016 [San Diego Comic-Con International](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-
Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con International").

In 1995, Miller relocated to Los Angeles to pursue an acting career.[10] He
has stated that his rocky road to stardom "was a long time in the coming and
there were a lot of upsets and a lot of failures and roadblocks, but I
couldn't walk away from it. I needed it like I needed air, it was just
something I had to do."[11] Miller's first TV appearance was as student-
turned-sea monster Gage Petronzi on _[Buffy the Vampire
Slayer](/wiki/Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer "Buffy the Vampire Slayer")_ ("[Go
Fish](/wiki/Go_Fish_\(Buffy_the_Vampire_Slayer_episode\) "Go Fish \(Buffy the
Vampire Slayer episode\)")", 1998).

Miller's first starring role was in 2002 as the sensitive, introverted David
Scott in [ABC's](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting
Company") [mini-series](/wiki/Mini-series "Mini-series")
_[Dinotopia](/wiki/Dinotopia_\(miniseries\) "Dinotopia \(miniseries\)")_.
After appearing in a few minor television roles, he moved on to co-star in the
2003 film _[The Human Stain](/wiki/The_Human_Stain_\(film\) "The Human Stain
\(film\)")_ , playing the younger version of the [Anthony
Hopkins](/wiki/Anthony_Hopkins "Anthony Hopkins") character, Coleman Silk. He
identified strongly with the core dilemma of the movie, about a black man who
chooses to "pass" as white. Miller worked extensively on the role, not only in
researching Anthony Hopkins, but by embarking on a four-month regimen to
accurately portray Silk as a boxer. Also in 2003, he had a minor role in the
film _[Underworld](/wiki/Underworld_\(2003_film\) "Underworld \(2003 film\)")_
, playing a doctor and friend of the character [Michael
Corvin](/wiki/Michael_Corvin "Michael Corvin").

In 2005, Miller was cast as Michael Scofield in [Fox
Network's](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company")
[television](/wiki/Television "Television") drama _[Prison
Break](/wiki/Prison_Break "Prison Break")_. He played the role of a caring
brother who created an elaborate scheme to help his brother, [Lincoln
Burrows](/wiki/Lincoln_Burrows "Lincoln Burrows") ([Dominic
Purcell](/wiki/Dominic_Purcell "Dominic Purcell")) escape death row after
being found guilty of a crime he did not commit. His character had a full
upper body (front and back) [tattoo](/wiki/Tattoo "Tattoo"). Covering both the
front of Miller's torso and his back, along with both arms from shoulders to
wrists, the special effects for the tattoo took over four hours to apply. His
performance in the show earned him a 2005 [Golden Globe
Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe Award") nomination for [Best
Actor in a Dramatic
Series](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actor_%E2%80%93_Television_Series_Drama
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama").[12] The show
was finished in 2009 after four seasons, but a new nine-episode [fifth
season](/wiki/Prison_Break_\(season_5\) "Prison Break \(season 5\)") was
released April 4, 2017 with Miller reprising his role.

Miller appeared in two [Mariah Carey](/wiki/Mariah_Carey "Mariah Carey")
[music videos](/wiki/Music_video "Music video"), "[It's Like
That](/wiki/It%27s_Like_That_\(Mariah_Carey_song\) "It's Like That \(Mariah
Carey song\)")" as a party guest and "[We Belong
Together](/wiki/We_Belong_Together_\(Mariah_Carey_song\) "We Belong Together
\(Mariah Carey song\)")" as her love interest. Director [Brett
Ratner](/wiki/Brett_Ratner "Brett Ratner"), who directed the pilot episode of
_Prison Break_ , was also signed on to direct the two Carey videos. Ratner
decided to use Miller in the videos as well.[13]

In addition, Miller guest-starred in the Season 11 premiere of _[Law& Order:
Special Victims Unit](/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit "Law & Order:
Special Victims Unit")_ as Detective Nate Kendall, a detective from Precinct
24 of the [New York City Police
Department](/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department "New York City Police
Department").[14][15] He also featured in _[Resident Evil:
Afterlife](/wiki/Resident_Evil:_Afterlife "Resident Evil: Afterlife")_ , the
fourth film in the commercially successful [_Resident Evil_ film
series](/wiki/Resident_Evil_\(film_series\) "Resident Evil \(film series\)")
based on the [video game series of the same name](/wiki/Resident_Evil
"Resident Evil"); Miller plays [Chris Redfield](/wiki/Chris_Redfield "Chris
Redfield"), one of the protagonists of the video game series.

Miller wrote the screenplay for the film _[Stoker](/wiki/Stoker_\(film\)
"Stoker \(film\)")_ , as well as a [prequel](/wiki/Prequel "Prequel") to
_Stoker_ , _Uncle Charlie_.[16] He used the [pseudonym](/wiki/Pseudonym
"Pseudonym") Ted Foulke, later explaining, "I just wanted the scripts to sink
or swim on their own."[17] Miller's script was voted to the 2010 "Black List"
of the 10 best unproduced screenplays then making the rounds in Hollywood.[18]
The film is about a teenage girl who must deal with a mysterious uncle
following the death of her father. Miller described it as a "horror film, a
family drama and a psychological thriller".[19] Although influenced by [Bram
Stoker](/wiki/Bram_Stoker "Bram Stoker")'s _[Dracula](/wiki/Dracula
"Dracula")_ , Miller has clarified that _Stoker_ is not a vampire
story.[19][20] Hitchcock's _[Shadow of a Doubt](/wiki/Shadow_of_a_Doubt
"Shadow of a Doubt")_ also influenced the film but only as a jumping-off
point, from which the story takes a different direction.[19] [Park Chan-
wook](/wiki/Park_Chan-wook "Park Chan-wook") directed, with stars [Mia
Wasikowska](/wiki/Mia_Wasikowska "Mia Wasikowska") as the teenager, [Nicole
Kidman](/wiki/Nicole_Kidman "Nicole Kidman") as the mother, and [Matthew
Goode](/wiki/Matthew_Goode "Matthew Goode") as the uncle.[21] The film was
released in 2013, and received generally positive reviews from critics.[22]

In July 2014, it was announced that Miller had joined the cast of [The
CW](/wiki/The_CW "The CW") [superhero](/wiki/Superhero_\(genre\) "Superhero
\(genre\)") series _[The Flash](/wiki/The_Flash_\(2014_TV_series\) "The Flash
\(2014 TV series\)")_ in a recurring role as [Leonard Snart / Captain
Cold](/wiki/Captain_Cold "Captain Cold").[23] He made his first appearance in
the fourth episode of the first season, and reprised his role on _[Legends of
Tomorrow](/wiki/Legends_of_Tomorrow "Legends of Tomorrow")_.[24] These shows
reunited him with his _Prison Break_ co-star [Dominic
Purcell](/wiki/Dominic_Purcell "Dominic Purcell"), who portrayed [Mick Rory /
Heat Wave](/wiki/Heat_Wave_\(comics\) "Heat Wave \(comics\)"). Miller exited
_Legends of Tomorrow_ as a series regular at the end of season one, but signed
a contract with [Warner Bros. TV](/wiki/Warner_Bros._TV "Warner Bros. TV") to
continue portraying Snart simultaneously on multiple shows in the
[Arrowverse](/wiki/Arrowverse "Arrowverse").[25]

Miller wrote the screenplay for the 2016 horror film _[The Disappointments
Room](/wiki/The_Disappointments_Room "The Disappointments Room")_ , produced
by [Voltage Pictures](/wiki/Voltage_Pictures "Voltage Pictures") and Killer
Films.[26] The film received negative reviews from critics.[27] He is
reportedly in negotiations to write the screenplay adaptation of the novel
_[The Story of Edgar Sawtelle](/wiki/The_Story_of_Edgar_Sawtelle "The Story of
Edgar Sawtelle")_ by [David Wroblewski](/wiki/David_Wroblewski "David
Wroblewski") which is set to be produced by [Oprah
Winfrey](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey "Oprah Winfrey") and [Tom Hanks](/wiki/Tom_Hanks
"Tom Hanks") among others.[28]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wentworth_Miller&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Wentworth_Miller_%2816791169033%29.jpg/220px-
Wentworth_Miller_%2816791169033%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wentworth_Miller_\(16791169033\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wentworth_Miller_\(16791169033\).jpg "Enlarge")

Miller in 2015

Miller lives in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), [British
Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada"). He has two sisters, Leigh and Gillian. He holds dual British and US
citizenship by virtue of his birth in the United Kingdom to American
parents.[20]

In 2007, Miller denied to _[InStyle](/wiki/InStyle "InStyle")_ magazine that
he was [gay](/wiki/Gay "Gay").[29] However, he [came out](/wiki/Coming_out
"Coming out") as gay in August 2013, when he posted a letter on
[GLAAD](/wiki/GLAAD "GLAAD")'s website declining an invitation to attend the
[Saint Petersburg International Film
Festival](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_International_Film_Festival "Saint Petersburg
International Film Festival") because he felt "deeply troubled" by the Russian
government's treatment of its gay citizens (referring to [Russian LGBT
propaganda law](/wiki/Russian_LGBT_propaganda_law "Russian LGBT propaganda
law") enacted the previous June which banned "propaganda of nontraditional
sexual relations").[30][31] Miller wrote that he "cannot in good conscience
participate in a celebratory occasion hosted by a country where people like
myself are being systematically denied their basic right to live and love
openly".[30]

At the 2013 [Human Rights Campaign](/wiki/Human_Rights_Campaign "Human Rights
Campaign") Dinner in [Seattle, Washington](/wiki/Seattle,_Washington "Seattle,
Washington"), Miller said he had attempted suicide multiple times as a
teenager before coming out as gay.[32] He said: "When someone asked me if that
was a cry for help, I said no, because I told no one. You only cry for help if
you believe there's help to cry for."[32] He discussed struggling in Hollywood
as a closeted actor, and talked about how his involvement in the [ManKind
Project](/wiki/ManKind_Project "ManKind Project") helped him learn about
brotherhood, sisterhood, and being part of a community.[33]

In a 2016 Facebook post, he revealed that he "[had] struggled with depression
since childhood. It's a battle that's cost [him] time, opportunities,
relationships, and a thousand sleepless nights." He made this emotional post
in reaction to a meme of himself which poked fun at his weight gain in 2010.
Miller said that his weight gain was due to him finding comfort in food as he
was suicidal.[34]

On October 17, 2016, [Active Minds](/wiki/Active_Minds "Active Minds"), a
mental health charity, announced that Miller will be Ambassador for the
organization.[35]
